result:
Determine the Parisian GHG budget

The amount of greenhouse gases the world can still emit to have a two out of three chance of staying below 1.5° or 2° warming until the end of the century is called the global greenhouse gas budget.
1.
Warming limit:
Please first choose the warming limit you would like to comply with.
The graph shows the dependence of risks and/or impacts associated with the Reasons for Concern (RFCs) on your chosen level of ‘tolerable’ global warming.
2,0 °C
1,5 °C
2.
Parisian share:
In order to come up with the Parisian share of the resulting global budget, you have to decide what you consider a fair share.
Either you choose that every person should be allowed to emit the same amount of greenhouse gases (“Per capita”), or you decide that Europeans should be allowed to emit less due to their above-average GDP (“Capability”).
{{shares[fairnessOption].title}} {{shares[fairnessOption].shares['EU28+1'][appState.budgetTemperature.toFixed(1)]}}
GT CO2 equiv.
Global budget (as of 2020): {{budgets[appState.budgetTemperature.toFixed(1)]}} GT CO2 equiv.
read intro start calculating

The global GHG budget is calculated using a transient climate response to cumulative CO2 emissions (TCRE) of 1.65C/TtC. These are roughly consistent with a 50% chance of reaming below budget if we assume a normal distribution of TCRE from 0.8-2.4C/TtC (5th-95th percentiles). They hold from 2020-2100 inclusive.

In order to split the GHG budget estimate into a EU27+2 and a Rest of the World (RoW) share we proceed as follows.

1) Choose a shape for the CO2 emissions time series between now and end of 21st century. This is chosen to be the shape which CO2 emissions follow in the representative concentration pathway 4.5 (RCP4.5). Note we are required to choose a shape because fairness weightings require time series of annual global CO2 emissions.

2) Rescale the RCP4.5 emissions time series so that it holds peak global warming over the 21st century below the level chosen by the user (i.e. either 1.5°C or 2.0°C). For this we use best estimates of the TCRE parameter to convert the cumulative CO2 emissions into a globally averaged warming response.

3) Apply the fairness approaches to the global emissions time series to find the EU share. We have 2 fairness approaches:
a) Per capita: Use the SSP2 population time series over the 21st century for EU27+2 and RoW to weight fair emissions by EU’s share of global population.
b) By capacity: Use the SSP2 population and GDP time series over the 21st century for EU27+2 and RoW to weight fair emissions for EU’s share of global wealth and population.

For a more complete description of methodology behind fairness calculation see Deliverable 1.2, Section 6.

In case you choose the 2° threshold, please be aware that it may be impossible to “park” the climate at 2° global warming.

Trajectories of the Earth System in the Anthropocene, Will Steffen et al. PNAS August 14, 2018 115 (33) 8252-8259; https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.1810141115
